guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

author.bio:
Professional Chrischan. Striving for post-Enlightenment reconciliation. I love Jesus and hate the antichrist. ✝️ #NotAll

Gab: https://gab.com/stevejail
author.bio_html:
Professional Chrischan. Striving for post-Enlightenment reconciliation. I love Jesus and hate the antichrist. ✝️ #NotAll

Gab: https://gab.com/stevejail

body:
Jesus commanded his followers to live in poverty, and often went on about how as a rule, the less you have materially, the more you'll have in the Kingdom of God.

So, the general direction we're looking in is obvious enough.

But this was also pre-atonement, and since that's not necessarily what Paul or the other Apostles taught later on, it becomes a more difficult question. I think the rule probably holds that poverty keeps you humble, and being humble will keep you closer to divinity. But it's also possible for a rich man to attain salvation through Christ's mercy. We don't withhold the sacraments from them, after all.

post.body: I personally get a little irritated when someone of wealth and stature says they follow Christ's teachings.
post.body_html: I personally get a little irritated when someone of wealth and stature says they follow Christ's teachings.
post.title: Is it possible to be a wealthy Christian?

body:
Not necessarily. Men running businesses are often seen as wealthy, even though the majority of their wealth is tied up in various business and assets. Those wealthy men can be a good force in the world, providing jobs, funding charities, and ensuring that the company will continue to profit so that those beneficiaries may continue to benefit. Jesus also told us parables about being good stewards of what we're given. 

If you're a capable businessman and you refuse to improve yourself or your business because you have the foolish idea that you have to constantly shed your wealth to get into heaven, you are no better than the servant who buried his talent underground until his master returned. 

We are all created with different gifts. We all have a responsibility to glorify God. Refusing to use your gifts out of fear is allowing the fear to control you rather than serving God. And the fear of not being allowed into heaven is no different.

parent.body:
Jesus commanded his followers to live in poverty, and often went on about how as a rule, the less you have materially, the more you'll have in the Kingdom of God.

So, the general direction we're looking in is obvious enough.

But this was also pre-atonement, and since that's not necessarily what Paul or the other Apostles taught later on, it becomes a more difficult question. I think the rule probably holds that poverty keeps you humble, and being humble will keep you closer to divinity. But it's also possible for a rich man to attain salvation through Christ's mercy. We don't withhold the sacraments from them, after all.

body:
I would guess it's more because our current political culture has created an idea among Christians that the wealthy are good and the poor are bad. The threat of socialists and people who sit on welfare because they're lazy is ever-present in the back of their minds, and conflation of faith and patriotism has made achieving the "American dream", a major component of which is obtaining wealth, part of Christian doctrine.

And the most famous pastors make hundreds of thousands per year from scamming people by charging them for their books, podcasts, etc.

body:
Speaking economically, you actually help more of the impoverished by making a billion dollars and donating 1% to charitable organizations, than you do by working at a soup kitchen on weekends. We don't really live in the same economic paradigm that we did pre Industrial Revolution, and especially not the same one as ancient Israel or ancient Rome.

You could say that they should give 10% or 50% away instead, I guess. But it's certainly not a simple question in any case.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: Eh, the pendulum swings both ways, which is why Christians are called to the straight and narrow. Yes there are mega churches spending entirely too much on shiny buildings and fancy equipment. But there are also many calls for communism these days and an insistence that if you're Christian you should own nothing. There is a straight and narrow Christ taught us, which is to use the blessings God bestows on you and your family and increase them so that you may bless others.

I would guess it's more because our current political culture has created an idea among Christians that the wealthy are good and the poor are bad. The threat of socialists and people who sit on welfare because they're lazy is ever-present in the back of their minds, and conflation of faith and patriotism has made achieving the "American dream", a major component of which is obtaining wealth, part of Christian doctrine.

And the most famous pastors make hundreds of thousands per year from scamming people by charging them for their books, podcasts, etc.

body:
I do agree with most of Paul's teachings, aside from his pride. The authentic ones that is, not the ones added in by the church fathers.

I also disagree that there's a "vow to poverty". The idea is not to withhold service to others who need it, not to intentionally deprive yourself (that's that fasting is for). The rich man was hoarding tremendous wealth and wouldn't spend a penny on his starving neighbors. This was all in a time when the Jewish doctrine was that God blesses the good with wealth and power and curses the wicked with poverty; but in reality many who are first will be last and many who are last will be first. I don't think there's anything wrong with having things, but it shouldn't come at the expense of the less fortunate. The earliest Christians evidently possessed things and shared it all with each other (willingly, not through communism). Of course, enduring poverty is honorable and certainly deserves a higher reward than someone who coasts through life with ease.

body:
Not at all. Jesus told his followers to keep nothing but a sword, not even the clothes on their back.

But you don't believe that's the best way to act, because of course you don't, it's ridiculous, and because that's never what the Church has been about. But that is was what Christ's personal discipleship was about. There's an inarguable separation there. I'd hardly say it was a Jewish institution or anything like that, Jesus spent something like 3/4 of his ministry telling the Jews (mostly Pharisees) that they're all going to Hell!

Re: Church Fathers and Revisionism. I'm not an infalliblist (is that a word?) but just for practical purposes, you kinda have to take the New Testament as a body of work or not, because it's literally impossible to know what's legitimate and what isn't. Homologoumena and Antilegomena certainly don't hold up as categories anymore. The Critical Scholars take their guesses, but they also have a habit of smelling smoke where no fire exists. Instead, it's best to take it as "good enough to get a pretty reasonable idea of what the ideal Christian archetype is."

That's also what the early Church Fathers were, and I don't think you can throw them out either. Not because of some wishful notion of consensus like the Roman Catholics have. They aren't perfect, but they're also a lot more connected to the society from which Christianity emerged than we can ever hope to be, they likely had knowledge and sources that we don't even know exist. A lot gets lost in transmission over two thousand years, even when it's written down, because the language fundamentally changes. The Fathers are our lighthouses.

The rich man was hoarding tremendous wealth and wouldn't spend a penny on his starving neighbors. This was all in a time when the Jewish doctrine was that God blesses the good with wealth and power and curses the wicked with poverty; but in reality many who are first will be last and many who are last will be first. I don't think there's anything wrong with having things, but it shouldn't come at the expense of the less fortunate. The earliest Christians evidently possessed things and shared it all with each other (willingly, not through communism). Of course, enduring poverty is honorable and certainly deserves a higher reward than someone who coasts through life with ease.

body:
I do wish that families could be more amiably under one roof, even with extended family, but I understand the complications causing households to be mostly nuclear only. Having extended family under one roof, or even just nearby in separate homes, makes a great deal of sense. Unfortunately it's usually functionally problematic. 

That said, I don't think either living nuclear family only nor extended multi family home are necessarily good or bad, inherently. It's more about how you live your life than where you live.

parent.body:
Not at all. Jesus told his followers to keep nothing but a sword, not even the clothes on their back.

But you don't believe that's the best way to act, because of course you don't, it's ridiculous, and because that's never what the Church has been about. But that is was what Christ's personal discipleship was about. There's an inarguable separation there. I'd hardly say it was a Jewish institution or anything like that, Jesus spent something like 3/4 of his ministry telling the Jews (mostly Pharisees) that they're all going to Hell!

Re: Church Fathers and Revisionism. I'm not an infalliblist (is that a word?) but just for practical purposes, you kinda have to take the New Testament as a body of work or not, because it's literally impossible to know what's legitimate and what isn't. Homologoumena and Antilegomena certainly don't hold up as categories anymore. The Critical Scholars take their guesses, but they also have a habit of smelling smoke where no fire exists. Instead, it's best to take it as "good enough to get a pretty reasonable idea of what the ideal Christian archetype is."

That's also what the early Church Fathers were, and I don't think you can throw them out either. Not because of some wishful notion of consensus like the Roman Catholics have. They aren't perfect, but they're also a lot more connected to the society from which Christianity emerged than we can ever hope to be, they likely had knowledge and sources that we don't even know exist. A lot gets lost in transmission over two thousand years, even when it's written down, because the language fundamentally changes. The Fathers are our lighthouses.

body:
Matthew is the Gospel people tend to take as the "canonical" account of events. That is to say, they're all canonical, but when people are reciting a synoptic event, if it's in Matthew, that's usually the version you're going to get, and there's a reason for that.

It's the most likely to be correct based on authorship traditions. Mark is a rough 2nd hand account from Peter's sermons, and Luke/Acts was written by a companion of Paul who most likely wasn't actually there for Christ's ministry.

body:
Mark and Luke are much more likely to be authentic, and Mark is also the oldest, not Matthew. I do believe Matthew probably wrote a gospel first, as there's no other reason to attribute something like that to him, however, that is definitely *not* the Matthew we have in our Bible today, which copies from Mark as does Luke. From what I've gathered the original Matthew was a short narrative written in Hebrew, consisting of a few major events but mostly just teachings and parables, just as described in the earliest times. This was translated into Greek and incorporated into Mark's and Luke's gospels as well as the current Matthew. Since our Matthew likes to expand and mix and reorganize things like many ancient writers, Luke is actually a lot closer to the original Matthew because he mostly opts for a more factual retelling without changing much aside from poorly written language. 

The reason Matthew is usually preferred is for exactly the reason I described, because people like flowery and memorable literature, and whoever wrote it had an amazing talent for that.

This was translated into Greek and incorporated into Mark's and Luke's gospels as well as the current Matthew. Since our Matthew likes to expand and mix and reorganize things like many ancient writers, Luke is actually a lot closer to the original Matthew because he mostly opts for a more factual retelling without changing much aside from poorly written language.

The reason Matthew is usually preferred is for exactly the reason I described, because people like flowery and memorable literature, and whoever wrote it had an amazing talent for that.

I do believe Matthew probably wrote a gospel first, as there's no other reason to attribute something like that to him, however, that is definitely *not* the Matthew we have in our Bible today, which copies from Mark as does Luke. From what I've gathered the original Matthew was a short narrative written in Hebrew, consisting of a few major events but mostly just teachings and parables, just as described in the earliest times. This was translated into Greek and incorporated into Mark's and Luke's gospels as well as the current Matthew. Since our Matthew likes to expand and mix and reorganize things like many ancient writers, Luke is actually a lot closer to the original Matthew because he mostly opts for a more factual retelling without changing much aside from poorly written language. 

The reason Matthew is usually preferred is for exactly the reason I described, because people like flowery and memorable literature, and whoever wrote it had an amazing talent for that.

body: You claimed Matthew is the most reliable gospel and a firsthand account and should take precedence over Mark and Luke. I disputed your claim because Mark came first and Luke follows older sources more closely, and Matthew was almost certainly not written by Matthew. I don't write off everything he says but I keep in mind that he paraphrases a lot and likes to add in metaphors and literary devices, and that can change the meaning. Compare the Sermon on the Mount with the Sermon on the Plain, or the two Lord's Prayers and you'll see what I mean.

body:
You misunderstood my claim. I said that his is the most commonly referenced, and then you went about discrediting it. But, you can't really, I could just as well call into question any of the 4 Gospels. We can't prove that they haven't been revised and altered (although if any one of them has, it's John, and we actually do have some compelling manuscript evidence for that.)

Why couldn't Matthew have been written by Matthew? I can't imagine it was attributed to him for no reason. Even if he referenced Mark or the Q document, it's actually not such an odd thing to do, if you want to make sure you aren't misremembering. Same can be said for Luke, memory is frequently fallible after all. I'm sure the critical scholars will come up with a reason to doubt, but as helpful as they are, they tend to exaggerate skepticism when it's uncalled for. I've seen it claimed that entire epistles should be removed because they quote the Septuagint instead of the Hebrew.

body:
John is definitely edited. Luke also underwent an anti-Marcion revision. Matthew had the virgin birth added at some point, other than that it's hard to tell. Mark is mostly left alone.

The gospels were not attributed until halfway through the second century. In fact they aren't used at all until Justin Martyr. The church fathers before that did mention things written down by Matthew and Mark, which is probably why their names are used; however Matthew at least does not fit the description of our Matthew, which even mentions Matthew in 3rd person. The Matthew they speak of was a collection of logia (sayings) which they specifically say were written in Hebrew. Our Matthew is a lot more than just some logia and is definitely not a translation from Hebrew. If he wrote it he waited quite a while to do so, and he relied quite a bit on second hand accounts even though Matthew should be a primary source.

> I've seen it claimed that entire epistles should be removed because they quote the Septuagint instead of the Hebrew.

There's nothing wrong with using a translation.

The church fathers before that did mention things written down by Matthew and Mark, which is probably why their names are used; however Matthew at least does not fit the description of our Matthew, which even mentions Matthew in 3rd person. The Matthew they speak of was a collection of logia (sayings) which they specifically say were written in Hebrew. Our Matthew is a lot more than just some logia and is definitely not a translation from Hebrew. If he wrote it he waited quite a while to do so, and he relied quite a bit on second hand accounts even though Matthew should be a primary source.

I've seen it claimed that entire epistles should be removed because they quote the Septuagint instead of the Hebrew.

There's nothing wrong with using a translation.

body:
Halfway through the 2nd century is not that late. They didn't attribute works the same way we do today, it was most likely assumed authorship. Is it possible it's wrong? Yeah, but that shouldn't necessarily be the default assumption.

On the issue of 3rd person reference: People usually didn't write narratives from the first person perspective in the ancient Near-East, and in fact, if they did, you would immediately pin it as a fraud, it's one of the most distracting elements of the Book of Mormon, for example.

The Gospel of John was most likely written by a man named "John-Lazarus" a principle character in the story of that Gospel, who was raised from the dead. We only know his proper name was John because Clement refers to him that way in his writings, and it's simply been misattributed to the Apostle John for most of Christian history because it's such a common name (there are similar issues with "Mary") But in that gospel as well, you have Lazarus writing the story from the third person.

Luke is the Gospel I know the least about, tbh. I'd be interested in knowing how it was revised against Marcion. Not that I really doubt it, but our manuscripts mostly date after him, so I'm not sure how you could be certain.

The Gospel of John was most likely written by a man named "John-Lazarus" a principle character in the story of that Gospel, who was raised from the dead. We only know his proper name was John because Clement refers to him that way in his writings, and it's simply been misattributed to the Apostle John for most of Christian history because it's such a common name (there are similar issues with "Mary") But in that gospel as well, you have Lazarus writing the story from the third person.

Luke is the Gospel I know the least about, tbh. I'd be interested in knowing how it was revised against Marcion. Not that I really doubt it, but our manuscripts mostly date after him, so I'm not sure how you could be certain.

body: Marcion's gospel seems edited too (he removed the baptism and the genealogy and anything supporting Judaism) but it's also got plenty of differences and missing content that Marcionites didn't have a reason to object to as far as we can tell, and in those cases they show signs of being later additions to canonical Luke. It also has things that contradict Marcion's theology which doesn't make sense if he merely went through Luke and took out everything he objected to. And something like 90% of the material missing from Marcion's gospel is unique to Luke. We also know that Luke has been revised in the past due to the quite obvious addition of the first two chapters.

And something like 90% of the material missing from Marcion's gospel is unique to Luke. We also know that Luke has been revised in the past due to the quite obvious addition of the first two chapters.

parent.body:
Halfway through the 2nd century is not that late. They didn't attribute works the same way we do today, it was most likely assumed authorship. Is it possible it's wrong? Yeah, but that shouldn't necessarily be the default assumption.

On the issue of 3rd person reference: People usually didn't write narratives from the first person perspective in the ancient Near-East, and in fact, if they did, you would immediately pin it as a fraud, it's one of the most distracting elements of the Book of Mormon, for example.

The Gospel of John was most likely written by a man named "John-Lazarus" a principle character in the story of that Gospel, who was raised from the dead. We only know his proper name was John because Clement refers to him that way in his writings, and it's simply been misattributed to the Apostle John for most of Christian history because it's such a common name (there are similar issues with "Mary") But in that gospel as well, you have Lazarus writing the story from the third person.

Luke is the Gospel I know the least about, tbh. I'd be interested in knowing how it was revised against Marcion. Not that I really doubt it, but our manuscripts mostly date after him, so I'm not sure how you could be certain.
parent.body_html:
Halfway through the 2nd century is not that late. They didn't attribute works the same way we do today, it was most likely assumed authorship. Is it possible it's wrong? Yeah, but that shouldn't necessarily be the default assumption.

On the issue of 3rd person reference: People usually didn't write narratives from the first person perspective in the ancient Near-East, and in fact, if they did, you would immediately pin it as a fraud, it's one of the most distracting elements of the Book of Mormon, for example.

The Gospel of John was most likely written by a man named "John-Lazarus" a principle character in the story of that Gospel, who was raised from the dead. We only know his proper name was John because Clement refers to him that way in his writings, and it's simply been misattributed to the Apostle John for most of Christian history because it's such a common name (there are similar issues with "Mary") But in that gospel as well, you have Lazarus writing the story from the third person.

Luke is the Gospel I know the least about, tbh. I'd be interested in knowing how it was revised against Marcion. Not that I really doubt it, but our manuscripts mostly date after him, so I'm not sure how you could be certain.

As far as I know Marcionism's biggest theme is the idea that the god of the old testament is different from the one in the new and is evil. Which to me sounds like someone just couldn't reconcile Christianity with the old testament because of the alterations made by scribes.

body:
(Edit: Deleted first sentence because I can't source it)

He wasn't technically Gnostic, but in the same way John the Baptist wasn't technically a Christian.

You can see echos of Marcionistic Dualism in a lot of the 3rd Century Gnostic Gospels. I think Judas and Mary both have it (although I'm iffy on Mary, it might've been a different work that happens to have Mary Magdalene as a central character.)

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body: Marcionism isn't actually Gnostic, it contradicts Gnosticism on major points. As far as I know Marcionism's biggest theme is the idea that the god of the old testament is different from the one in the new and is evil. Which to me sounds like someone just couldn't reconcile Christianity with the old testament because of the alterations made by scribes.

post.body: I personally get a little irritated when someone of wealth and stature says they follow Christ's teachings.
